security_audit.summary: Legitimate computer vision engineering skill. All 53 static findings are false positives: scanner misidentified 'SAM' (Segment Anything Model) as Windows SAM database, 'algorithms' as crypto code, and markdown backticks as shell execution. Python scripts are skeleton templates with no malicious code, network calls, or credential access.

content.value_statement: Computer vision projects require deep expertise in architectures, optimization, and deployment. This skill provides senior-level guidance for building object detection, segmentation, and real-time vision systems with production best practices.
actual_capabilities: Design and implement computer vision architectures including CNNs, vision transformers, and YOLO models
Optimize inference pipelines for latency and throughput in production environments
Build data processing pipelines for image and video datasets
Implement object detection, segmentation, and visual AI systems
Apply MLOps practices for vision model deployment and monitoring
Integrate OpenCV, PyTorch, and SAM for comprehensive vision solutions
limitations: Does not execute training or inference directly. Provides guidance and code patterns only
Requires user to implement actual model logic in provided skeleton scripts
No pre-trained models included. User must supply or train their own

output_examples.input: Help me create an object detection system for traffic monitoring
output: Recommended architecture: YOLOv8 for real-time performance
Data pipeline: Process video streams with OpenCV, apply augmentations
Training: Use PyTorch with mixed precision for faster training
Inference optimization: TorchScript export, TensorRT acceleration
Deployment: Docker container with Triton inference server
Monitoring: Track latency, throughput, and detection confidence

output_examples.input: Create a segmentation pipeline for medical images
output: Model choice: SAM (Segment Anything Model) for flexible segmentation
Data preparation: DICOM processing, annotation workflow
Integration: PyTorch dataset class with proper transforms
Fine-tuning: LoRA adapters for medical domain adaptation
Validation: IoU metrics, expert review process

output_examples.input: How do I optimize my vision system for edge deployment
output: Model quantization: INT8 quantization with calibration
Pruning: Remove redundant filters for smaller model size
Runtime: TensorRT or ONNX Runtime for GPU acceleration
Hardware: Consider Jetson or TPU for edge inference
Batching: Optimal batch size for latency vs throughput trade-off

best_practices: Profile inference latency before optimization. Measure where time is actually spent
Use batch processing and caching strategically to improve throughput without compromising latency
Implement proper input validation and sanitization for vision system inputs
anti_patterns: Deploying models without proper monitoring. You cannot improve what you cannot measure
Skipping data quality validation. Garbage in produces garbage out
Ignoring model drift. Production vision systems degrade over time as data distributions shift

faq.question: Which vision model should I use for my use case?
faq.answer: YOLO models excel at real-time object detection. Vision transformers work well for tasks requiring global context. SAM is ideal for segmentation tasks

faq.question: What are the latency targets for real-time vision?
faq.answer: Target P50 under 50ms, P95 under 100ms, and P99 under 200ms for real-time applications

faq.question: How do I integrate this skill with my existing ML pipeline?
faq.answer: Use the provided Python scripts as templates. They accept input and output paths for seamless integration with data pipelines

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill provides guidance only. All processing happens in your environment. No data is sent externally

faq.question: Why is my inference slower than expected?
faq.answer: Check GPU utilization, optimize data loading with prefetching, use mixed precision, and consider TensorRT or ONNX export

faq.question: How does this compare to using cloud vision APIs?
faq.answer: This skill helps build custom vision solutions. Cloud APIs are easier but less flexible and have ongoing per-request costs
